SEARCH
Package gw.api.modules.rest.framework.v1.resources

Class RestResource

java.lang.Object
gw.api.modules.rest.framework.v1.resources.RestResource
Direct Known Subclasses:
RestCollectionResource, RestElementResource
public abstract class RestResource extends Object

Parent class for all rest resources.

This includes collections, which should be subclasses of RestCollectionResource, and single elements, which should be subclasses of RestElementResource.

This class should not be extended directly, but rather one of its subclasses should be used. Which subclass of those to extend depends on the underlying object backing the resource, and whether the resource is a root resource or not.

The underlying object backing a collection resource is typically a database query or a stream. The underlying object backing an element resource is typically an entity or a plain Java/Gosu object. A resource may also not have an explicit underlying object, and control its response directly; see hasVerbatimResponse() and buildVerbatimResponse()

A root resource is one with no parent. Given an endpoint path to access a resource, the resource's parent is usually the resource "above" it in the path. This may be ambiguous if there are multiple endpoints that can access a given resource, but the resource should have a single canonical path from which the actual parent can be determined.

A collection resource accessed by the path "baseUrl/states" is a root resource, whose children are State resources. A collection resource accessed by the path "baseUrl/states/stateId/cities" is a non-root resource, whose parent is a State resource and whose children are City resources.

An element resource accessed by the path "baseUrl/states/stateId" is a State resource whose parent is a States collection resource. An element resource accessed by the path "baseUrl/openapi.json" is a root element resource with no parent.

    • getCanViewException

      public RestRequestException getCanViewException()
      This method can be overridden to handle cases where the user is permitted to view this resource, but this resource isn't viewable for some other reason related to the object's state. Return null to indicate that the resource is viewable, and return RestRequestException to indicate that the resource is not viewable and why.

    • getParent

    • canPerformAction

      public abstract boolean canPerformAction(String method, String customAction)
      Indicates whether or not the specified HTTP method and custom action can be invoked by the currently-authorized user on this resource. This method is used to determine what links should be generated on responses.
      Parameters:
      method - the HTTP method in all lower-case, such as "get" or "post"
      customAction - the custom action, if any, such as "assign" or "complete"
      Returns:
      true if the currently authenticated user can invoke the given method and action, false if not

    • hasVerbatimResponse

      public boolean hasVerbatimResponse()
      This flag indicates whether or not the resource wants total control over the response that goes back out on the wire. If this property returns true, then buildVerbatimResponse() will be called to create the response body for the request. Otherwise, the standard processing flow will be used.

    • buildVerbatimResponse

      public Object buildVerbatimResponse()

      public String getETag()
      Override this property if the resource supports caching
